channel.title: Denver Homeless Out Loud
channel.description: Posts from Denver Homeless Out Loud

item.title: 2B or not 2B “Measure 2B will raise about $40-million a year,...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

2B or not 2B

“Measure 2B will raise about $40-million a year, which will be used to acquire, build or remake 1,800 homes in the next ten years, “
---------
We have 10 times that many homeless people now... so that is 1% of the need every year for 10 years. Anybody noticed if homelessness has been increasing or decreasing for the past 20 years... It has certainly been increasing more than 1% a year. It is not going to change if we do not respond at scale. Think 10 times wh...at they are talking with this legislation.

In addition there is no provision in the legislation to assure that funds will actually get allocated to housing. Most of it will end up being spent on services.

https://www.thedenverchannel.com/…/voter-approval-of-denver…

See MoreVoters in the Mile High City have approved a .25 percent sales tax hike, to help fund more housing and services for the homeless.

thedenverchannel.com

Voter approval of Denver ballot measure 2B called 'monumental'

Voters in the Mile High City have approved a .25 percent sales tax hike, to help fund more housing and services for the homeless.Voters in the Mile High City have approved a .25 percent sales tax hike, to help fund more housing and services for the homeless.
item.author: Denver Homeless Out Loud

item.title: Imagine you need a new roof so you gutters don't get...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Imagine you need a new roof so you gutters don't get clogged all the time. Then some folks come by and say hey we would like to clean your gutters... and you respond with I would really rather have my roof fixed so that when you clean the gutters it will mean something. Otherwise you all will just have to return to clean the gutters all the time and we will get nowhere.

This is often what happens with “services” for the homeless. They are often things that do not lead t...o solutions. Sure things may be better for a short time but since the real issue is not addressed the need never goes away. So if the person in the above story said “no thanks for you gutter cleaning, I am going to look for someone to fix my roof” and the gutter cleaner call them “ungrateful”. What do you call the gutter cleaners. I think the current term being used is “KAREN”. Local news coverage is unfortunately made from a KAREN point of view all too often.

The problem with 2B is that it will lead to the equivalent of a lot of gutter washing without fixing any roofs so over time things will not get better they will worsen. Housing ends homelessness not a bunch of services that have to be repeated over and over and over us because there is no housing. Build the housing Denver #DoBetter.

City council turned down a master lease amendment to the city budget last Monday. That would have ended homelessness for many quickly, but they turned it down 12-1. What kind of council would complain about too many visibly homeless folks and refuse to budget for an option that would end it. We call them KAREN.

https://denver.cbslocal.com/…/denver-homeless-measure-appr…/

See MoreThe money will be used for building housing, expanding rental assistance, and expanding access to 24-hour shelters and services.

denver.cbslocal.com|By CBS Denver

Denver Voters Approve Sales Tax Increase To Fund Services For Homeless

The money will be used for building housing, expanding rental assistance, and expanding access to 24-hour shelters and services.The money will be used for building housing, expanding rental assistance, and expanding access to 24-hour shelters and services.
item.author: Denver Homeless Out Loud

item.title: Sweep of Encampment at 22nd and Wazze Tuesday After a week off...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Sweep of Encampment at 22nd and Wazze Tuesday

After a week off for elections, the City is back at their solution to homelessness...sweeping people from block to block...

...
After a week off for elections, the City of Denver is back at it, planning to sweep the encampment at 22nd and Wazze on Tuesday (11/10). There are about 60 people living at this site. Most of these residents have been swept multiple times in the past couple months.

Instead of funding trash services for encampments like this one so they can properly dispose of their trash, City Council voted down this budget amendment on Monday and left it to the Mayor to keep sweeping people like trash instead of just sweeping trash.

Moving people who have nowhere to go with no answer does not work. It is time we start using our brains and our hearts, instead of continuing this shameful whack-a-mole.

Please come and support our unhoused community members at 22nd and Wazze and support residents of this encampment as they demand real housing or places where they are allowed to survive.

Bring the following things to assist residents:

-Truck, or any vehicle to help move

-Carts

-Bungee Cords

-Rope

-Trash Bags

-Food

-Coffee/CoCo

-Water

Your assistance is much appreciated! Somewhere around 6:30am and all morning help will likely be needed.

Toward Rights, Dignity and Housing…

See More
item.author: Denver Homeless Out Loud

item.title: One month ago today... The city has increased frequency and...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

One month ago today... The city has increased frequency and intensity of sweeps since. Wasting all that money, some of the folks at the camp near by the rally are now off of 6th and Sherman right next door to a news station that seems not to notice. What an opportunity for a story, what will they do when the police fence off the block and they can't get in and out of the news station.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BXebm8JZqsc

October 5th 2020 A lawsuit and motion for preliminary injunction was filed against the City of Denver for violating constitutional rights of homeless individ...

item.title: Sunday was the 5th annual Day of Dignity and we were there. ...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Sunday was the 5th annual Day of Dignity
and we were there. Covid led to less engagement from other orgaizations but was still was a great event. Lookng forward to next year when we expect that covid will have finnaly passed us by.

+6
item.author: Denver Homeless Out Loud

item.title: Denver CAN Fund Sanitation Resources and Housing for the...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Denver CAN Fund Sanitation Resources and Housing for the Houseless: Demand Council VOTE YES for these budget amendments on Monday

On Monday, November 2nd 2020, City Council will be voting on amendments to the Mayor’s proposed budget for 2021. They have the power to move money from police to housing and sanitation resources for those living without housing.

Councilwomen Candi CdeBaca is proposing amendments to fund trash services for encampments and master leasing of housing ...for people without housing. These funding amendments are on the agenda for council to vote on Monday:

We NEED Trash Services for Encampments and Housing through City Master Leasing.

City Council needs to hear from YOU that we the people are demanding Housing Not Police! We are demanding Sanitation Resources Not Police!

Sign up for general public comment on Monday (Sign up starts Friday at 12noon and goes fast - see this link to sign up https://www.denvergov.org/…/general-public-comment-session.… )

Email your council person (or all of them!) and demand they vote YES for sanitation and housing proposals. https://www.denvergov.org/…/denver-cit…/council-members.html

Together we DEMAND Housing and Sanitation NOT Police.

Contact:

info@denverhomelessoutloud.org

720-940-5291

See More
item.author: Denver Homeless Out Loud

item.title: "Bulldozers and dump trucks. That’s what the city offered...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

"Bulldozers and dump trucks. That’s what the city offered our unhoused neighbors this freezing morning. Not the promised SOS sanctioned camp site initially approved at the same location by the Mayor who then backed down after lobbying by the Five Points Business District — which has offered no solutions. Even though the pandemic is worsening, scattering people in this cold-hearted way shows whose lives are disposable in this city."

Denver Homeless Out Loud was live.
item.author: Denver Homeless Out Loud

item.title: Denver CAN Fund Sanitation Resources and Housing for the...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Denver CAN Fund Sanitation Resources and Housing for the Houseless: Demand Council VOTE YES for these budget amendments on Monday

On Monday, November 2nd 2020, City Council will be voting on amendments to the Mayor’s proposed budget for 2021. They have the power to move money from police to housing and sanitation resources for those living without housing. We as DHOL have sent council five budget amendments to move money from police to these basic human needs. Our proposals i...nclude funding for port-a-potties and handwashing stations at encampments, trash services at encampments, water at encampments, hotels for all those staying in congregate shelters, and housing for all those counted homeless in Denver.

City Council needs to hear from YOU that we the people are demanding Housing Not Police! We are demanding Sanitation Resources Not Police!

Sign up for general public comment on Monday (Sign up starts Friday at 12noon and goes fast - see this link to sign up https://www.denvergov.org/…/general-public-comment-session.… )

Email your council person (or all of them!) and demand they vote YES for sanitation and housing proposals. https://www.denvergov.org/…/denver-cit…/council-members.html

Together we DEMAND Housing and Sanitation NOT Police.

Contact:

info@denverhomelessoutloud.org

720-940-5291

See More

item.title: Boulder is currently severely limiting access to shelter,...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Boulder is currently severely limiting access to shelter, including limiting severe weather walk-up shelter to 30 nights for the season, and blocking people who have not been residents for 6 months from anything but a few days in shelters there.

"Boulder Shelter has rearranged its layout and is currently offering 140 of its 160 total beds — or about half of the 282 beds that were available before the consolidation.

Along with the new location, the policies for severe weathe...

Continue ReadingJust after 9 a.m. on Sunday, Oct. 25, Mark pokes his head out from his sleeping bag, double-wrapped in a crinkled emergency blanket for extra warmth. He’s lying underneath one of the bridges near Boulder’s main library downtown.  His eyes are squinty, his nose bright red. It’s about 10 degree...
